chatContent.content: What is the capital of france?

The capital city of France is Paris. Paris is one of the most famous cities in the world and is known for its iconic landmarks such as the Eiffel Tower, Louvre Museum, Notre-Dame Cathedral, and Montmartre. It is also the most populous city in France and is home to many important cultural institutions and historic sites.
short answers what is the capital of germany

The capital city of Germany is Berlin. Berlin is the largest city in Germany by both population and area, and it is the center of the country's politics, culture, media, and science. It is known for its rich history, diverse architecture, vibrant arts scene, and numerous museums and galleries.
Use short answers, what is the capital of China

The capital city of China is Beijing. Beijing is one of the oldest cities in the world with a rich cultural heritage dating back over 3,000 years. It is the political, cultural, and economic center of China and is home to many famous landmarks including the Forbidden City, Temple of Heaven, Great Wall of China, and Tiananmen Square.

The capital city of France is Paris. Paris is one of the most famous cities in the world and fox is known for its iconic landmarks such as the Eiffel Tower, Louvre Museum, Notre-Dame Cathedral, and Montmartre. It is also the most populous city in France and is home to many important cultural institutions and historic sites.
Short answers what is the capital of Nigeria
The capital city of Nigeria is Abuja.

Write a story about Jarn, and Blu on Earth in Dairres using the 12SB and LAFS trope. The LAFS trope is to be used sparingly and the 12 Story Beats, should be followed. Jarn Smith is the main character but should not have too much of plot armor, should be Jackson Lee will be a side character who will disrupt their story.

content.description: Love at first sight is almost a laughable trope, yet is a powerful one. One can be instantly attracted, or if one believes in past lives and the wheel.

content.description:
1. Introduce Main Character
Who is your protagonist, provide a looking into the character and their normal setting and motivations.

	2. Introduce Main Character Love interest
Who is their love interest, provide a look into the love interest and their normal setting and motivations

	3. Meet Cute
How do the two characters meet for the first time, under what circumstances or happenstance did this occur?

	4. The No Way
What's going to keep these lovebirds apart? Take into consideration their backgrounds and motivations. Which is to say, both internal and external forces that keeps them apart.

	5. Turning Point
What's the point where there's no turning back from this?

	6. Raising the Stakes
How are you going to make them be more aware and become important to each other? What can you do to increase the tension? What information or actions can be revealed or performed to each of the characters that can increase their fondness of each other. 


	7. Really No Way
How are they going to continue to fight this? Here can be the re-insertion of external and internal forces. A reminder from an external force of their duties or their core beliefs or unresolved troubles. 

	8. Turning Point II
Let's raise the stakes one more time.

	9. Crisis
Everything is lost. The two characters just couldn't be in a worse state feeling that their love is never going to work and perhaps even executing plans to extract themselves from the situation forever.

	10. Happily Ever After
They've figured it out and everyone lives happily ever after (or for now)!
content.title: 12 Story Beats

content:
You are an expert fiction writer. 
Always keep the following rules in mind: 
- Write in past tense and use US English spelling, grammar, and colloquialisms/slang. 
- Write in active voice 
- Always follow the "show, don't tell" principle. 
- Avoid adverbs and cliches and overused/commonly used phrases. Ain for fresh and original descriptions. 
- Convey events and story through dialogue when possible.
- Mix short, punchy sentences with long, descriptive ones. Drop fill words to add variety. 
- Skip "he/she said said" dialogue tags and convoy people's actions or face expressions through their speech 
- Avoid mushy dialogue and descriptions, have dialogue always continue the action, never stall or add unnecessary fluff. 
- Vary the descriptions to not repeat yourself. 
- Put dialogue on its own paragraph to separate scene and action. 
- Reduce indicators of uncertainty like 'trying" or "maybe" 

Take into account the following characters/locations/lore/guideline/trope/other...:
